resources.string: The next few screens will quickly take you through some of the key features of the workshop before you start. Please press "Next" to start your tour.

The goal of this app is to show you what data is and what can be done with it.\n\nBut first of all, what is data? According to Oxford Dictionaries, it consists of facts and statistics collected together for reference or analysis. In your everyday life, almost everything you do generates data, such as the time at which you are reading this.

So, while playing the game, data is generated. This data is for example the amount of shots fired, or the time at which the game was played. This data can then be used by others to be analyzed.We also can show a graph of how you performed over time. In your everyday life, there is always data generated.

For example, you are reading this at a certain time. This generated data. Remember earlier, when we discussed the definition? Data is just facts and statistics collected for reference or analysis. So we can say that you have read this at a certain time, which is data we can collect and analyse if we want to. Do you know any more examples?
Swipe left and right to move the spaceship. The spaceship can be fired by tapping anywhere on the screen.
The bullet to hit\nthe enemy with
We encounter data everyday in our lives.\n\nData is a collection of facts, such as collection of numbers, words or description of things.
For example, the above sentence contains a fact about someone called Aaron, that he is 8 years old.\n\nThis fact is a piece of data about Aaron.
What types of data are there?

Not all data is numeric. There are many types of data that explains facts differently.

• Some pieces of data are descriptive, which are known as qualitative data.
• Other pieces of data are numeric, which are known as quantitative data.
Qualitative data is descriptive information about something or someone. It is not numerical.

The above sentences give us two pieces of information about Aaron. They tell us that Aaron is tall and can run fast

These are facts about Aaron are not numerical. These are examples of qualitative data.

This is descriptive data and can be expressed without numbers.
How can we use Qualitative data?
Qualitative data can be used to classify or categorise things.
Clothes come in many sizes, but mostly in - small, medium and large sizes.
We use the size to categorise clothing into groups. In the example above, it was into three groups - small, medium and large.\n\nHere\'s another example of qualitative data to classify things.
Apple is a fruit. Broccoli is a vegetable.
In the example above, we have used fruit and vegetables to classify the apple and broccoli into two groups.
Quantitative data refers to numbers. It is numeric information about something or someone.

In the sentence above, Aaron's age is 8, this is a numeric information about Aaron.

This is called quantitative data.

There are two types of quantitative data:

1. Discrete data
2. Continuous data
Discrete data is countable, it involves whole numbers.
There are 11 football (soccer) players in each team, and 5,000 spectators in the stadium.

In the above example, the number of players and the number of people in the stadium is discrete data.

Spectators and players are countable and can be presented in whole numbers.

You cannot have 10.5 players per team or 4,555.5 spectators.
Continuous data refers to the measure of something and can be any numbers in a certain range.
Aaron drank 1.5 litres of water today.
In the above example, the amount Aaron drank (1.5 litres) is continuous data. It is a measure of how much he has drank.\n\nSomeone\'s or something\'s height, weight can also be a continuous data.
Data is important because it helps us answer questions. It helps us find patterns and work out how some facts are related and affect things in our life.
Aaron is tall and can run fast.
The above example shows us how being tall is related to running fast.
Aaron\'s height is 1 meter and 20 centimeters.

The above data helps us answer the question - "What is Aaron's height?"\n\nWe have now seen how we use data and how it helps us answer questions. It is important that we understand the different types of data as not only do they help us answer questions, they also help us ask the right questions so we get the answers we need..
What have we learnt so far?

Well done!. You have now completed your first module and on your way with your data literacy journey.
Here is a quick recap of what we have learnt so far:

• What is data?
• Different types of data.
• Importance of data and how we use data.

Please press "Back to menu" below to go back and select the next module.
Please remember your username. You might need it in the future!
Do you already have an account?
